bioghist.p: Edna Phillips worked for the Massachusetts State Division of Public Libraries as Secretary of Work with Foreigners and as Supervisor of Work with Racial Groups. For this work, she was awarded the Dante medal from Ravenna, Italy. During World War I, she served in France and Germany as a canteen worker for the YMCA. She was one of the first six women to serve with the army of occupation in Germany.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of personal and professional papers of Edna Phillips. Materials include: correspondence between Phillips and family and friends while she was stationed in France and Germany; subject files on a range of topics, including Thoreau and Gandhi; lecture notes on books and travel; knitting patterns; a scrapbook of clippings related to her work for the Massachusetts State Division of Public Libraries; and slides, photos, and published materials about American Friends Service Committee work camps in the United States and abroad. The collection also contains a sketchbook, several childhood stories, and items related to Phillips's mother's family, the Macys. These materials include a scrapbook, a photo album, and loose photographs.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
